description: Borrowed from Latin articulātus (“distinct, articulated, jointed”).

adjectives.description: articulate (comparative more articulate, superlative most articulate)

entries.meaning: Speaking in a clear and effective manner.
examples: She’s a bright, articulate young woman.

entries.meaning: Consisting of segments united by joints.
examples: The robot arm was articulate in two directions.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Expressed in articles or in separate items or particulars.
(obsolete, of sound) Related to human speech, as distinct from the vocalisation of animals.
examples: Brutes cannot form articulate Sounds, cannot articulate the Sounds of the Voice, excepting some few Birds, as the Parrot, Pye, &c.

entries.meaning: (zoology) An animal of the subkingdom Articulata.
examples: They considered articulates to be pre-adapted for an eleutherozoic existence because they possess muscular arms which are potentially of value in crawling and swimming, as in comatulids.

verbs.description: articulate (third-person singular simple present articulates, present participle articulating, simple past and past participle articulated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To speak clearly; to enunciate.
examples: I wish he’d articulate his words more clearly.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To explain; to put into words; to make something specific.
examples: I like this painting, but I can’t articulate why.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bend or hinge something at intervals, or to allow or build something so that it can bend.
(music, transitive) to attack a note, as by tonguing, slurring, bowing, etc.
(anatomy, intransitive) to form a joint or connect by joints
examples: The lower jaw articulates with the skull at the temporomandibular joint.
